coredata.dc:title: Characterization of two different adsorption states for O on Cu(100). Ionic versus covalent bonding
coredata.dc:creator: Arvanitis, D.
Comelli, G.
Lederer, T.
Rabus, H.
Baberschke, K.
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
By means of temperature-dependent surface extended X-ray absorption fine-structure measurements, two different chemisorption states of O atoms on a Cu(100) surface were confirmed. From a systematic discussion of N and O on Ni(100) we deduce that for reconstructed substrates the bond is more covalent, for the unreconstructed ones more ionic. For the latter case we can determine the charge transfer to the ad-atom to be 0.92(3) e in agreement with theoretical calculations, based on a Madelung form of the pair potential.

A comparison of the pair-potential parameters with the ones for the sys- tems 0/Ni(l00) and N/Ni(l00) allows us to dis- tinguish the bonds corresponding to an unrecon- structed from the ones corresponding to a reconstructed surface. Based on this comparison it is proposed that the 0 Cu bond is predominantly ionic for the unreconstructed state, confirming theoretical calculations F41. A discontinuity in all pair-potential parameters as a function of decreasing bond length for the reconstructed system, is tentatively inter- preted as an increase of the degree of covalency of the low-Z adsorbate metal bond. The data were measured using the 5X700 I and II monochromators at the storage ring BESSY. The samples were prepared by exposure to oxygen either at 500 K (1200 L), and alternatively at 300 K (300 L) and then measured at 300 or 50 K in contrast to almost all other studies. In the first case a sharp overstructure was observed in con- trast to the second one where only broad LEED spots were observed around the positions corresponding to a e(2x2) structure, indicating poor long-range order. Experimental evidence for the existence of a different adsorption state than (~hx2~/~)R45 , at low oxygen exposures at 300 K can also be found in recent literature [7] in agreement with the previous The characterization of the oxygen copper inter- action is a long-standing problem, best illustrated (j) by the existence of two copper oxide forms, known to involve a different amount of charge transfer be- tween the O and Cu atoms. This charge transfer (ii) plays also a key role in the nccurrence of supercon- ductivity in high-temperature superconductors F 1]. Here we investigate (iii) the interaction of O atoms with a Cu( 100) surface. For this system different adsorption geometries were proposed from recent theoretical 12 41 and experimental studies F 5 10]. Most of these studies focus on the (I~ X 2%J~ )R45 state for which evidence exists that the Cu( 100) surface reconstructs F 2,5,6,9 11]. How- ever theoretical calculations F31 have also predicted an unreconstructed state, also in agreement with ex- perimental observations F 7,8,121 ~ based on tech- niques that do not require long-range order. In the present Letter using temperature-dependent surface extended X-ray absorption fine-structure (SEX- AFS) measurements we characterize two states for chemisorbed O on Cu(l00), one corresponding to the reconstructed and the other to an unrecon- structed surface. For example, an eventual relaxation of two of the Cu atoms towards the missing row by 0.3 A [5], yields an increase in static disorder of less than 3 X 10~ 42, more than one order of magnitude smaller. Supporting the previous interpretation two distinct adsorption states, one with a more ionic bond, with the adsorbate sitting above the surface, the other more covalent with the adsor- bate in the surface plane, were also recently pro- posed for 0/Al( 111) from theoretical calculations [22]. The previous discussion ties the decrease of the low-Z adsorbate metal atom bond length and the occurrence of surface reconstruction to a charge in the nature of the nn bond, which in the present ease is proposed to be more covalent than in the recon- structed ease. This finding cannot however serve as a general rule. For example, in the ease of an alkali atom-induced reconstruction of a metal surface, the reconstructed bond is found to be more ionic [23]. A comparison of the previous cases serves to illus- trate the strong nn bond length variation of the dif- ferent mechanisms responsible for the occurrence of surface reconstruction. As in the alkali-metal inter- action, the nn bonds are considerably longer, of the order of 3 A [23]. A more detailed comparison of these cases goes beyond the scope of the present Letter. In the ease of the well-known 0/Ni(lOO) system often taken as a prototype of an ionic adsorbate substrate interac- tion, a value of 0.89 electrons has been obtained for the O atoms excess charge, from a tight binding cal- culation [24]. tt has also been found that this charge is supplied almost exclusively from the first layer Ni atoms. This find- ing is also consistent with the theoretical result, that most of the O excess charge is supplied by the first Ni layer [24]. As the O bond to the three Cu in plane atoms shows a stronger co- valent character one can assume that the excess charge relative to the precursor state will mainly in- volve the Cu d electrons. However even if one uses the same q, = 1.5 e as in the precursor ease, a q,=0.40 e does not seem to be sufficient for the Cu atoms to reach a 3d9 configuration as in CuO. It appears that for both the 0/Cu adsorption states the 0 Cu atoms are found to be in a different electronic configura- tion than the one known in bulk oxides [1]. It is re- markable that the model-dependent parameters, q~q,, are found to be close to the calculated values. Fur- ther temperature-dependent SEXAFS studies will al- low better quantification of the previous analysis. In conclusion the schematic arrangement of the present and previous SEXAFS data in fig. 3 can be interpreted in the following way: one group of bonds (gray area) shows weaker repulsion, less charge transfer and shallower potentials. This group shows no adsorbate induced reconstruction. The second group (dotted area) has shorter bond lengths, stronger repulsion, larger charge transfer and deeper potentials. This can be interpreted as greater cova- lent bonding. All the latter cases show an adsorbate induced reconstructed surface. The amount of charge donation by Cu does not reach the amount necessary to go from 3d to 3d9 as discussed in the 0 Cu in- teraction in high T~s and bulk oxides [I]. Never- theless, the present study may serve as a model with a clearly defined local geometry for future general discussion. As an example, a link may be drawn be- tween the 0 Cu missing row reconstruction, the lo- cal geometry of the 0 Cu planes in high T,s and the respective electronic configurations of the 0 Cu pair. ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: By means of temperature-dependent surface extended X-ray absorption fine-structure measurements, two different chemisorption states of O atoms on a Cu(100) surface were confirmed. From a systematic discussion of N and O on Ni(100) we deduce that for reconstructed substrates the bond is more covalent, for the unreconstructed ones more ionic. For the latter case we can determine the charge transfer to the ad-atom to be 0.92(3) e in agreement with theoretical calculations, based on a Madelung form of the pair potential.
